elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children with a game, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
How do the people in the story feel?
Read for enjoyment, pointing out how the people feel as well as the shapes around them.
Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes—circle, square, rectangle, triangle—using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points or angles.
Initiate play and join a group in play.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts; Use perception to guide movement through space and interactions with objects and people.
Have children pair shapes with real-world objects that are the same shape.
Guide children to recognize similarities in objects of the same shape.
How can we express ourselves through music and dance?
What book did you choose? Why did you choose that one?
What music do you like to dance to?
What can you make with Pattern Blocks?
Can you write about your favorite song? Why do you like it?
What can you draw that is made of shapes?
start with? How do you make that letter?
What shapes are the blocks you are using?

Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to notice how to invite someone to play and to review shapes.
Offer an extended play opportunity, during which children practice inviting a friend to play.

Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes—circle, square, rectangle, triangle—using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points or angles; Create, compose, decompose, and talk about common two-dimensional shapes, including circle, square, rectangle, and triangle.
Initiate play and join a group in play.
Engage in conversations with a variety of partners, taking turns listening and speaking.
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.
Guide children to invite a partner to work together to draw.
Challenge children to work with partners and draw as many items as possible that are a basic shape such as a triangle, circle, or square.
How can we express ourselves through music and dance?
What shapes do you see in that book?
Show how you can invite a new friend to play with you.
Look at these pieces. Which pieces are circles and which pieces are squares?
Write a note inviting a friend to play.
How can you make a circle? How can you make a square?
start with? Can you write those letters?
Which shaped block is easiest to build with? Why?

Use Circle Time to review patterns, engage children with a song, and introduce the vocabulary
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,
How does the music change how the people in the book feel?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to recognize patterns in the rhymes.
Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes—circle, square—using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points or angles.
Recognize, complete, extend, duplicate, and create common patterns, including A, B, A, B; AA, BB, AA, BB; and ABC, ABC.
Engage with trusted adults and peers to work, communicate, and play.
Engage in conversations with a variety of partners, taking turns listening and speaking.
Create patterns using two colors of Connecting Cubes.
Guide children to identify a mistake made in the pattern.
Invite children to fix the mistake.
How can we express ourselves through music and dance?
Are there any rhyming words in your book? How do you know?
Can you pretend to play music on an imaginary instrument?
Can you draw different shapes? Which shapes?
Can you write a story that has rhymes in it?
How can you use shapes to draw a picture?
sound. Can you trace or write the letters
Do you see square blocks? Do you remember the name for an object that is made of six sides that are all squares?

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas for Old MacDonald's Farm. Chart shows a horse, a cow, goats, ducks, chicks, and a chicken in front of a farmhouse.

elements.text: Big Chart of Big Ideas:  Old MacDonald’s Farm
Use Circle Time to play a pattern game, notice rhyme in song, and introduce vocabulary words
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Read interactively and connect to patterns by showing how parts of the song repeat with each animal.
Recognize, complete, extend, duplicate, and create common patterns, including A, B, A, B; AA, BB, AA, BB; and ABC, ABC.

Create, compose, decompose, and talk about common two-dimensional shapes, including circle, square, rectangle, and triangle; Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes—circle, square—using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points  or angles.
Initiate play and join a group in play.
Guide children to invite friends to work together.
Have children create ABAB and AABB patterns using simple shapes.
Challenge partners to continue the patterns started.
How can we express ourselves through music and dance?
Are there any farm animals in your book?
Pretend to be one of the animals from Old MacDonald’s farm. What do you sound like?
How can you make a farm animal out of shapes?
Can you write a song or story with rhymes in it?
Draw a picture that has a pattern in it.
Which was your favorite animal sound? What letter sounds do you hear in it?
Build towers in a pattern of tall, short, tall, short.

TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Every Little Thing by Cedella Marley, illustrated by Vanessa Brantley-Newton. Text copyright © 2012 by Cedella Marley. Illustrations copyright  © 2012 by Vanessa Brantley-Newton. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Chronicle Books LLC.

Use Circle Time to dance, sing, and go on a shape count.
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,
What part of the song in the book reminds you of your life?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement as well as a focus on shapes.
Recognize, complete, extend, duplicate, and create common patterns, including A, B, A, B; AA, BB, AA, BB; and ABC, ABC.

Create, compose, decompose, and talk about common two-dimensional shapes, including circle, square, rectangle, and triangle; Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes—circle, square—using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points or angles.
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
Share a time that music and dance made you feel happy.
Save children’s responses to display next week.
How can we  express ourselves through music and dance?
How do the people or animals in your book share how they feel?
Can you make up a dance to express yourself? What does your dance show?
Create a pattern of shapes. What shape comes next?
Write a song about yourself and how you feel.
Can you create artwork using your favorite shape?
What sound do you hear in the beginning of the word
What is the biggest shape you can build?

Increasingly interact and communicate with peers to initiate pretend play scenarios that share a common plan and goal.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Coordinate sequence of movements to perform tasks.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Increasingly interact and communicate with peers to initiate pretend play scenarios that share a common plan and goal.
Engage in conversations in appropriate ways.
Use a variety of art materials and activities for sensory experience and exploration.
Share and celebrate class-made and individual written products.
Engage in conversations in appropriate ways.
Coordinate sequence of movements to perform tasks.
Share and celebrate class-made and individual written products.
